title: EDM Music Production: Do famous EDM producers mix their own tracks since they've gotten famous? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say they definitely do.  A lot happens in mixing that defines the flavor and aesthetic of the track. Ideally, with experience, mixing is occurring simultaneously with production: in EDM production it is almost impossible to define where one ends and the other begins.  For example, I always need to mix the drum and bass elements as I lay them down to know if they're going to work in concert, and at that time I have to make some song-defining decisions in eqing priorities (i.e. who gets to dominate in the crucial low mids). Through this process of mixing issues are discovered with certain sounds, which then need to be replaced or worked out (for example, a bassline might need to be lowered an octave to stop it conflicting with a kick drum, or the kick drum might need to be replaced). Production and mixing are constant and overlapping. The truth is; a powerful way to approach production itself is through the lens of mixing. Ideally, the sounds and their sequencing should fall together in such a way that a "mixing phase" to clean it all up is largely unnecessary. If you're spending hours eqing a sound and manipulating its dynamics to let it play nice with the other sounds, it could mean that it was just a bad call using that sound in the first place. Being able to reverse or make new production decisions because of issues in the mix is precisely why it shouldn't be outsourced to someone else.

I’m not sure how high profile an EDM producer would have to be to be considered ‘famous’ by the asker of this question but I’m certainly getting plenty of mixing work from people who’ve been on magazine covers etc… Quite often it is because the producers are busy travelling and are still making tunes on their laptops. Other times it’s just to have access to another perspective or the sound you can get from the very best equipment.

I am pretty sure Calvin Harris mixes his own songs (he only sends them to mastering engineer). Most of the EDM composers do mix their songs, though I am sure that there are some who don't. If you are able to mix a song for an hour and half good for you, this is good timing. However, for most EDM composers the process of arrangement and mixing comes together, they mix the song while they produce. This is how I do my self, wether it is an EDM track or no.

some do and some don't, lets be honest tho most are ghost producers so they dont even make their own songs e.g dada life send there mixes off to be mastered by someone else as they believe its better to have fresh ears master, but producers such as nosia mis and master their own.  its all down to personal preference and the artists ability
